title: My Weirdly Good Pineapple Tallow Balm Situation
body:
Okay so. I was just sitting here, my foot was totally asleep from how I was sitting on the couch, and I put some of this pineapple tallow balm on my hands. The smell made me think of this whole thing. I guess I should explain. I’ve been using this beef tallow skincare stuff for a few months now. The one I got smells like pineapple. It’s from some shop on Etsy. My skin was being a disaster this winter, all tight and angry, and I went down this internet rabbit hole about traditional stuff. Landed on tallow. Beef fat. For your face. I know. It sounds like something you’d cook with, not smear on your cheeks. But my grandma, she always had this little tin of something waxy for her knuckles. Never knew what it was. Maybe it was this. Anyway, I was desperate, so I got the Whipped Tallow Balm in Pineapple. And now I’m just… here. With better skin. It’s weird.

## How I Even Got Here (The Beef Fat Rabbit Hole)

It started in, like, November. The air got that dry, static-y feel. My face just gave up. I was using this expensive lotion that came in a fancy bottle. Did nothing. Felt like I was putting water on sand. So one night, I’m scrolling, my phone light is way too bright, and I read about beef tallow for skin. Not new. Ancient, actually. People have been using rendered animal fat forever. Before there was a whole aisle at Target for creams. Pioneers used it. Our grandparents probably used it. It’s just… tallow. From grass-fed cows. They whip it up until it’s this soft, creamy balm. The big thing is it’s supposed to be super similar to the oils our own skin makes. So your skin recognizes it. Doesn’t just sit on top. Sinks in. The whole natural skincare comeback thing, I get it now. It’s not a trend, it’s just going back to what worked before we made everything in a lab with unpronounceable names. I was skeptical. Obviously. Putting beef fat on my face felt like a joke waiting to happen. But I ordered the pineapple one because the scent sounded less intimidating. “Tropical escape.” Sure. Why not.

## What This Pineapple Stuff Actually Does

So it arrives. Little jar. Feels substantial. I open it. Texture is… interesting. Not hard. Not runny. Like if cold butter and whipped cream had a baby. You scoop a tiny bit. It melts the second it hits your finger. I put it on the back of my hand first, as a test. My skin drank it. No greasy film. Just gone. And the smell. It’s pineapple. But not like candy or a cleaning product. It’s like the idea of a pineapple. Sweet, but not stupid sweet. Cheerful. Makes me think of a vacation I never took. It’s a mood. I started using it at night. After I wash my face, I take a dab, warm it between my fingers, and just press it in. My face feels… calm. That’s the only word. Not shiny. Not sticky. Just calm. Like it finally got a drink after being thirsty. I use it on my elbows too. And my lips. The chapped lips thing? Gone in like two days. It’s become my everything balm. I keep it on my nightstand. The jar is from France, which feels fancy, but I got it from this little Etsy shop called Mount Heritage. Just a person making it, I think. That feels better somehow.

## My Skin Now vs. Then (Or, Winter Lost)

Before this tallow balm, winter won. My skin was a flaky, tight mess. I’d wake up and it felt like a mask. Now? It’s just my skin. But the good version. It doesn’t freak out when I go outside. It doesn’t get that red, irritated look after I shower. It’s just… settled. I don’t have to think about it. That’s the biggest thing. I don’t have a 12-step routine. I have this one jar. I use it when I remember, which is most nights. Sometimes in the morning if it’s really cold. The pineapple smell is a nice way to start the day, honestly. Better than coffee sometimes. My hands don’t crack at the knuckles anymore. I used to get those little painful splits. Not this year. I’m on my second jar now. I got one for my mom too, for her dry hands. She called me and was like “what is this magic?” She didn’t even blink at the beef tallow part. She just said it worked. That’s the whole point, right? It just works. I spent more on that fancy bottle of nothing. This little jar of whipped beef fat did more. Life is funny.

## Would I Buy This Pineapple Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. I already did. That’s the answer. I don’t do that with stuff. I get bored. I move on. But this is just a staple now. Like toothpaste. It’s there. It fixes the problem. No drama. The scent is this happy little bonus. It’s not medicinal. It’s not “spa-like” whatever that means. It’s just pineapple. A sweet, tropical, vacation-in-a-jar feeling. Makes the whole ritual feel less like a chore and more like a tiny treat. For sensitive skin, for dry skin, for just… skin that exists in winter, it’s a game-changer. A quiet, unassuming game-changer that comes in a simple jar. If you’re curious about this whole traditional tallow skincare thing, I’d say start here. With the pineapple one. It’s the friendliest gateway to beef fat for your face you could imagine.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, weirdly. It sounds wrong but it makes sense. Our skin’s natural oil, sebum, has a similar structure. So the tallow balm sort of tricks your skin into thinking it’s its own stuff. It absorbs deep. Doesn’t just coat the surface. It’s like giving your skin food it actually knows how to eat.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Not in my experience. And I can get clogged pores. The whipped stuff is non-comedogenic, which is a fancy way of saying it shouldn’t block pores. It melts in so completely it doesn’t leave a pore-clogging layer behind. My skin feels clear, not congested.

**What does the pineapple tallow balm smell like?**
Like a ripe pineapple got sunshined on. It’s sweet and fruity but not fake or overwhelming. It’s cheerful. It smells like summer, which is a nice trick to pull off in the middle of winter. Doesn’t linger all day, just a nice little scent when you apply it.

Anyway. If your skin is being difficult with the cold, and the usual stuff isn’t cutting it, this might be worth a shot. I’m just some person on the internet, but my skin’s happy. That’s all I wanted.
